candidates.description:
William Jefferson Clinton came from nowhere. From a house off Park Street in Hope, Arkansas, to the highest office in the land, his journey feels almost like a Hollywood script. To get here, he challenged conventions and broke traditions, often hand in hand with Hillary, branding himself as a ''New Democrat'', the antidote to the liberal losers of days gone by.

He launched a crusade for change, not just against Republicans, but against the ossified politics of his own party. If he can lead the nation while staying true to these principles, re-election should be easy. But public opinion is fickle — every bit as slippery as his own charm. Even in these good times, the Big Dog must tread carefully to avoid being dragged into the mire of Washington, where the muck can swallow a man whole.

Al Gore has always dedicated himself to the people he serves. In Congress, he’s been labeled at various times as a business-savvy Atari Democrat, a Southern-fried conservative, and an environmentalist crusader. The truth? He has always aligned himself with what he believes to be best for the country, even if it meant straddling factions. The senator’s son, a Vietnam vet, has always cared more about duty than some silly label.

When he was added to the ticket, pundits were baffled, two young Southern Democrats? Yet, alongside Slick Willy, he charmed the nation and helped usher in a new political era. Now, from his seat at the Naval Observatory, his role in the administration remains undefined. But one thing is clear: he is the natural heir apparent, and, like it or not, he will remain by his boss’s side.

questions.description: It’s like living in a museum. You sit back in the Oval Office, winter morning light resting in the windows, and stare at the portraits of your predecessors. It’s charming—but you need to get to work. The inauguration was just a few days ago, and already the sheer weight of the job is settling in. America’s healthcare system yearns for reform, and you’ve got a chance to deliver. A question lingers on your mind, however: Who should lead the charge?

answers.description: Well, Hillary, of course. She’s as smart as they come, and she’s been working on these issues her whole life. If anyone can sit down with the moderates, talk to ‘em, and get ‘em on board, it’s her. She’s got the talent, the heart, and the grit to get it done.
answers.feedback: She embraces you when you finally tell her the news, her eyes gleaming with delight. She can’t thank you enough for trusting her with the cornerstone of your agenda. She’ll get it done, you can feel it. You know damn well she’s smart and determined enough to pull it off. But what’ll the media say?

answers.description: Ted Kennedy has spent his life fighting for healthcare, it’s his mission, his legacy. And if anyone has the passion and the influence to bring people together and get the votes we need, it’s Ted.
answers.feedback: Kennedy explains he's not compromising. You knew this, you just thought you could persuade him, like you've done with almost everyone. Though he'd be glad to help, he'll stop at nothing to get universal healthcare passed. It's his world on this front, and you're just along for the ride.

answers.description: I can’t think of a better team to bring this party together than George Mitchell and Tom Foley. If anyone can work side by side to deliver clear, thoughtful healthcare policy, it’s those two.
answers.feedback: Partnering with Mitchell and Foley remains your best shot at producing a workable bill, one that can satisfy all wings of the party, and maybe even bring along a few moderate Republicans. The left might keep hungering for more, but in this climate, it's a lot better than nothing.

answers.description: Let’s bring the doctors, the health insurers, and the experts together to lead this effort. If we’re gonna do this right, we need the people who know the system inside and out, and who can help us get it done.
answers.feedback: Al, the Atari Democrats, and the growing Clinton coalition of business and middle-class voters appreciate the approach, because for you, the only real path to reform lies in depoliticizing the issue by anchoring it to the credibility of doctors, science, and research.

questions.description: A month has passed, and it still feels surreal to be in the White House, to actually be the President. You're starting to get used to it all. As you’re eating lunch, along with a leftover box of chocolates Hillary gave you for Valentine’s Day, Mack McLarty rushes in, his face pale. He creeps over to you and whispers, ''Bill, the World Trade Center has just been bombed.'' Your heart sinks, and you immediately rush into the Situation Room. You hang your head and think of a decision.

answers.description: Good Lord. My thoughts and prayers are with those who lost their lives. Hillary and I will travel to New York City to mourn the victims and pray for their families, while honoring their memory. At this moment, that’s all we can do.
answers.feedback: It’s a somber Saturday evening in New York City. A candlelight vigil surrounds the basement entrance as you join the mourning crowd. You embrace and console the families who lost their fathers, husbands, and friends, promising them that you, and the American people, will never forget this tragic day.'

answers.description: Jesus Christ. How on earth did they let this happen? This is unacceptable, We need to know who did this. Put out a quick statement so we can start, and let's coordinate with the FBI and Governor Cuomo to determine who was responsible and uncover why this happened.
answers.feedback: Years would pass before Ramzi Yousef and his co-conspirators were caught and arrested for the bombing. While many may have already forgotten the attack, those who lost loved ones that day never will, and you surely won't. Even if there really wasn't, you feel like there was something you could do to prevent this.

answers.description: No one punches us without getting punched back. Once we find out who is responsible, we’ll strike back swiftly and decisively, understood?
answers.feedback: You soon locate the culprits and order an airstrike on the suspected training camp where the attack was planned. There are still questions for many, but the American people are satisfied with your strong response, and the victims can get some form of justice.

questions.description: Twelve years of the Gipper and Old Man Bush’s so-called ''fiscal responsibility'' have left America drowning in a new kind of red scare, not communism, but debt. Tax breaks for the wealthy drained the public coffers, and by fiscal year 1992, the nation faced a recession and a $290 billion deficit. Now, your economic team, Bentsen at Treasury, Panetta at OMB, Reich at Labor, and Rubin as economic advisor, clash over the path forward. Bentsen urges deficit reduction to restore investor confidence, while Reich argues for policies to tackle stagnant wages and drive broad consumer spending.

answers.description: I’ll go with Bentsen’s plan: let’s focus on reducing the deficit to keep Greenspan and the investors on board. We’ll balance spending cuts with tax increases, smart and steady. Look, we’re not ‘tax-and-spend’ Democrats anymore, and it’s time folks knew it!
answers.feedback: Some less overtly hostile Republicans are pleasantly surprised by your pivot. There's been an influx of deficit hawks as of late, so you may find a moderate coalition to push it through. Still, most liberal Democrats are not thrilled about applying a chainsaw to the economy. But who knows? Maybe you'll even get Ross Perot to shut up about that, at least.

answers.description: I know folks are uneasy, but I’m putting my faith in Reich here. We’ve got to invest in building up the middle class first, that’s how we grow the economy. The deficit? We’ll tackle it once we know the full picture, but we can’t cut our way to prosperity.
answers.feedback: For the first time in you-don’t-know-how-long, you’ve heard Jesse Jackson, of all people, offer genuine praise for your plan. However, even with the peace dividend, it’s a pivot that won’t go over easily with the new deficit hawks. It’s an uphill battle, but if you defeated Bush, you can surely make it work. Right?

answers.description: Let’s focus on what we promised, reducing the deficit. It's gonna take a herculean effort, but we can do it. Mix in both budget cuts and new taxes, and let's pull our secret weapon: pivoting. Cut taxes where we can, push for wage growth, and make sure working families see real relief. And let’s be clear, we’re not backing down on expanding the Earned Income Tax Credit.
answers.feedback: You've got the ambitions of a newly minted president, that's for sure. People are already pushing the Anderson quote, that you can't increase spending, lower taxes, and balance the budget all at the same time. Still, with the peace dividend and some shrewd politicking, you just might manage to have your cake and eat it too.

questions.description: As soon as you spoke of plans to have the deficit divided by the end of your term, everyone dreamt up their own plans on how to go about it. Most Republicans despise the prospect of raising taxes on the rich, and many in our own party are considering the energy tax hike and tax cuts to be too ambitious. It's supposed to be something that will please everyone, and yet, everyone is gritting their teeth.

answers.description: Let's make it simple: that plan can have tweaks, but no massive changes. We've got a deficit and mountains of debt to recover, as well as an immense burden on the middle class. I've made promises, and I will follow them.
answers.feedback: And so, barely a few month in your presidency, you're already brawling with Congress. You barely relent with slightly lowering the tax on gas and abandoning the cut for the middle bracket to a simple tax credit, but it barely satisfy anyone more. It's not going good.

answers.description: I know that some of them would rather die than increase the tax on the richest in society by a single percentage point, but there are some who can be swayed. If we can build a long-term coalition, we should do so now. We can give way on that energy tax, for example, and offer a smaller middle-class tax cut.
answers.feedback: Once you found yourself open to cutting one part of your plan, the GOP flocked to see what else they could get. You quickly slowed their ambition but by the end, you've got more people on your side than before, including ''small c'' conservatives like Danforth. Looking at it, you may have your promises made reality, technically.

answers.description: There must be other avenues we could use to seduce them. I know it's pork, but if we can give those representatives and senators a few more wins for their constituents, I'm certain they'll agree to sign on the dotted line. It's always about give and take, after all.
answers.feedback: If it were just two years ago, it might have worked out. However, today, pork is seen extremely unfavorably, and while they don’t make a stir about it, you barely convinced anyone with those. It’s going to be tough to get anything through.

questions.description: As soon as you began to speak of large cuts and balancing the budget, people could hear the chainsaw being revved up. Bentsen's grin, shining as clear as a Texas day, signals his plan to reach equilibrium by 1998. However, people are beginning to get cold feet, as some of those cuts, combined with tax hikes, may actually be too great and depress our rebounding growth. Still, who are we to pass such debt on to future generations?

answers.description: We've got the numbers, I know that. We have a plan and the people to support it, in both parties. Why do we have to hear all their grievances when they clearly represent a deeply minor and unpopular part of America? No compromises have to be made.
answers.feedback: And so the chainsaw cuts and tears. High income tax, up. Corporate tax, up. Fuel tax, up. AMT rate, up. Medicare, down. Social Security, down. Medicaid, down. Now, the wolves are eyeing the great prize of the military with hungry eyes.

answers.description: While I know what I was elected on, that doesn’t mean we should close our eyes to what others might see as good. Some parts are better left untouched, after all. Let’s set up a commission to see what can be cut and what should be kept. A bipartisan commission, of course.
answers.feedback: The commission’s work would have slowed the budget quite a bit if its job wasn’t already cut out for it. It explained how each dollar given to different brackets equaled a different amount of return to the economy. It was simple, it was clear. While the tax increases would continue, most of the plans for welfare cuts were scrapped, focusing on inefficiencies first and foremost.

answers.description: Gore had some proposals we could get through. It’s very novel, but we could tax those big businesses that pollute more than any others. How about taking that plan of fiscal responsibility and using it to push our ecological goals? Either the deficit hawks will show themselves as hypocrites, or we’ll seize a real opportunity for innovation here.
answers.feedback: Pushing this new ''Carbon Tax'' as fiscal responsibility made a lot of Republicans, and even some Democrats, extremely queasy, especially in coal and oil states. You could see how hard Byrd was trying not to make a fool of himself when he spoke of the need not to undercut American business against international competition while being assaulted on the question of the deficit. It's easy to strike when you're not the target, as always.

questions.description: When it began to look like you were becoming one of those ''tax and spend'' Democrats, the shields of the Republican Party and deficit hawks were raised high and strong. To make anything like this come to pass, you'll have to use some ''voodoo magic,'' as Gore said. People are calling it way too ambitious and decrying it as going against basic economics. Yet, you have to get through it

answers.description: There’s a first thing to do right, we need to secure clear support from everyone in our own party first. It’s too much for any Republican, but if we can speak of urban and rural renewal to those more doubtful states, we might just straddle the line.
answers.feedback: Pork as always? When you first managed to convince Byrd that West Virginia could be renewed, you thought it was going to go smoothly. However, the deficit hawks are powerful, and they’re not liking what they’re seeing. It’s going to be particularly difficult.

answers.description: We need to make it about poverty and growth. It’s about giving the opportunity to the average American to be all that they can be. If we can’t have something clear behind closed doors, we need something that’ll apply pressure from the outside.
answers.feedback: In an America that's recovering from Reagan and Bush, you're just speaking of giving more handouts to more people. It's a culture war between people down on their luck and people who don’t see why their dollar should be spent on others. It's one you cannot win.

answers.description: I'll have to speak with Reich about it. When I approved his plan, it was more about starting high, then negotiating to something achievable. It's nothing against him, but in its current form, the plan is just not going to work out.
answers.feedback: Reich gritted his teeth but relented, as it was clear the national mood wasn’t for something so ambitious while that one Texas giant was speaking of balancing the budget. As you lower the tax cuts and spending, more people begin to listen, but it’s still a long way out.

questions.description: Justice Byron ''Whizzer'' White is retiring, giving you your first Supreme Court vacancy. A Kennedy appointee, he’s seen as a lapsed liberal, more cautious than strictly ideological. The process is long, the press is restless, names rise and fall, and every choice carries risk. You’ve talked it through with Al, your Cabinet, and others, but the decision is yours.

answers.description: I'm gonna go with Ruth Bader Ginsburg. She's a Carter appointee, and a person that liberals will love. More importantly, she’s the kind of nominee who can win confirmation without a dragged-out fight. The Court needs sharp minds, and she’s one of the sharpest.
answers.feedback: You champion Ginsburg’s nomination, pointing to her experience on the U.S. Court of Appeals for D.C. and her reserved, moderate persona. As the second woman on the Court, she’s historic, but she doesn’t stir up much controversy, aside from some positive, if vague, headlines for your administration. Good, that's just the way you like it.

answers.description: Bruce Babbitt, Secretary of the Interior, former Arizona governor. He’s got the experience, the temperament, and a record that shows he can navigate the law and politics. He’s no stranger to tough fights, and I like that about him.
answers.feedback: Babbitt was one of the first names you came up with. Just a few months ago, he sailed through Senate confirmation as Secretary of the Interior without a hitch. But now, Senators Hatch and Dole aren’t happy about the idea of him on the Court, calling him too political. Still, you have the numbers to push through your former DLC ally, if you’re willing to fight for him.

answers.description: I don’t care what they’re saying. Laurence Tribe is nothing short of a genius, probably the best legal mind of his generation. This decision sets a tone for my presidency; we’re moving forward, not back. The Court should reflect that.
answers.feedback: Though he’s not quite considered a radical, Mr. Tribe, a longtime Harvard professor, is viewed as a liberal pick by both the GOP and the media. You needed to throw them a bone anyway. Al wasn’t a fan, apparently calling Tribe an ‘oddball,’ but you don’t really care, and you don’t have to.

answers.description: I'm going with Webster Hubbell. I know we had him in mind for Associate Attorney General, and I’m sure Janet wouldn’t mind. He’s someone I can trust, and, you know, he’s a good ol' boy from back home. He’s got the right instincts and the right heart for the job.
answers.feedback: You knew it was risky to go with Mayor Hubbell, but you couldn't have imagined how bad the whiplash would be. He’s being pulled into the Whitewater abyss, and his entire reputation, his very being, is being slowly melted away. You quickly realize there's no way he's getting confirmed, and you drop him as fast as possible and end up appointing Janie Shores.

answers.description: Judge Stephen Breyer. He’s thoughtful, measured, the kinda guy who understands more than the letter of the law, but how it breathes out there. And look, y’know, he’s the kind of nominee who can make it through the Senate without a bunch of noise. I like that.
answers.feedback: Stephen Breyer had been on your mind for a long while, right near the top of the list. When you finally give him the call, he sounds cool. Earlier, you’d hoped for a little more passion from him — but that calm, that steadiness, it feels right. Hatch quietly recommended him, while Ted Kennedy lobbied, and Breyer looks set to clear the Senate without much trouble.

questions.description: The GOP and the press are desperate for something, anything, to get you on. Travelgate, Troopergate, Nannygate — you can’t even get a haircut without the press crying foul. But no matter the scandal du jour, it always comes back to Whitewater: a years-old land investment deal you and Hillary entered into back in Arkansas that lost money and stirred up questions that never seem to die, questions that feed the fever dreams of your loudest enemies. Something has to be done. But what?

At night, when you finally get a chance to sit down and watch some TV with Hillary, and despite your best efforts to focus on the onscreen drama, she’s eager to tell you about her attempts to sway Congress in favor of her healthcare reform. She vents about ''not being treated like the politician she is'' or something along those lines, insisting that her efforts are going well. Obviously, you don’t entirely believe her, but you decide to trust your wife. Then she asks for your input on who to work with. You know exactly what to do, Slick.

After a month, which has felt like a millennia since you've entered office, Ted can finally get back to you on the healthcare. He informs your he's been working his ass on the initiative, trying to get droves of Democrats on board. He insures you it can be done, but it's going to take a herculean swing to get it done. He asks you to give him suggestions for the reform getting passed, and you know just what to do.

You're in the Oval Office, doing paperwork, when Mitchell and Foley stride into the room to discuss healthcare reform. They inform you of their plans: mandating insurance, forcing businesses to provide coverage for employees, and subsidizing those on the short end of the stick. It’s a rather moderate proposal, but they’re confident this is what can be passed with relative ease. You, staying true to Hillary’s dream, feel this proposal is too watered down to be called real ''reform.'' But at the same time, there’s the matter of getting something passed. They ask for your opinion, but they’ve already made it clear what they want to do. But you know best, don’t you, Slick?

The healthcare plan has finally been unveiled, and it's a disaster. You should have known letting the pharmaceutical corporations have a say was a bad idea. They simply took almost all the talking points from the HEART Act, and slapped on more tax breaks for healthcare businesses. You're enraged, you're not letting this see the house floor, so you might as well kill it before it gets the chance.

As soon as the Berlin Wall fell, there was a beast that grew to a truly bloated size that everyone wanted a piece of: the military. Only the most delusional hawks want to keep it as it is, but they have the votes to stop us from fully using the peace dividend the way we should. It's just a question of how much, and how.

Following months of tense operations in Mogadishu, the Somali people have turned against the U.S. and UNOSOM II forces after a botched raid on a villa owned by warlord Mohamed Aidid, which resulted in the deaths of many innocent women, children, and community leaders. The incident has rightly sparked outrage from human rights organizations, who have labeled it a massacre. It is clear to you that you must quickly change tactics to salvage what little support remains among the Somali population; otherwise, the situation could escalate unpredictably.

At this point, it feels like every day brings another mess you’ve inherited from the Bush administration. No wonder you kicked his ass so badly. Crime skyrocketed under Reagan and only got worse under 41, hitting an all-time high merely three years ago. You made it clear to Reno from day one that something had to be done, and now, after months of back-and-forth, she’s pushing for reform. You’re finally weighing your options. What’s your move?

At this point, it feels like every day brings another mess you’ve inherited from the Bush administration. No wonder you kicked his ass so badly. You made it clear to Reno from day one that something had to be done, and now, after months of back-and-forth, she’s pushing for reform. You’re finally weighing your options. What’s your move?

Your plans to allow members of the homosexual community to serve openly in the military have faced serious resistance from military leadership, as expected, but now, conservatives and religious leaders from St. Louis to Baton Rouge are piling on. Military generals are even threatening to resign en masse if it's allowed. After a lot of discussion, General Colin Powell presents you with a compromise: recruiters won’t ask about an individual's sexual orientation, but the military will retain the right to discharge those who are openly gay. It sounds tempting to bite the bullet and move on, but backlash from gay rights activists is already brewing, your cabinet is divided, and you’re caught in the middle.

Another unfortunate inheritance from the Reagan years: a slew of scientific projects marked by bloated costs and questionable value. The Texas Super Collider and the International Space Station are now under bipartisan attack, seen by many as overambitious endeavors with little practical return, as a coalition of deficit hawks lines up to cut them to pieces.

It’s finally time to sign the North American Free Trade Agreement, a landmark bipartisan deal designed to lower tariffs and eliminate trade barriers between the United States, Mexico, and Canada. Besides a little pushback from Perot and the Midwest, the agreement sees almost universal approval. You're taking some credit from 41 as well, who really got the ground running for this, so that's a plus. The ink on the agreement feels heavier than paper, it carries the weight of the entire continent.

It’s finally time to sign the North American Free Trade Agreement, a landmark bipartisan deal designed to lower tariffs and eliminate trade barriers between the United States, Mexico, and Canada. Besides a little pushback from Perot and the Midwest, the agreement sees almost universal approval. You're taking some credit from 41 as well, who really got the ground running for this, so that's a plus. The ink on the agreement feels heavier than paper, it carries the weight of the entire continent.

Just a few years ago, the U.S. and Russia were mortal enemies, teetering on the edge of mutual destruction. Now, at what some are calling ''the End of History,'' your friendship with Boris Yeltsin is so close that critics and supporters alike compare it to a love affair. Standing here in the Kremlin, with Russia’s fragile democracy hanging in the balance, and its economy lurching through a painful transition, what will you prioritize in these negotiations?

Standing here in the Kremlin, with Russia’s fragile democracy hanging in the balance, and its economy lurching through a painful transition, what will you prioritize in these negotiations?

That budget was a slog to get through but here we are now! It's finally going to be voted on. You have more than the majority of congressmen needed to pass it but the last few month have made it very clear that this doesn't mean much as those cross party coalition pushing for special interest have made themselves clear. Now, there's just one way to see.

Now, there's justone way to see.

Although the world looks calm and peaceful heading into the post-Soviet era, you know damn well that’s far from the truth. From genocides to brutal civil wars, negligent leaders, particularly in the Third World, couldn’t care less about their people’s suffering. But you remind yourself: you're not like them. You just need to pick your battles.

You woke up this morning feeling more stressed than ever at this job-and that’s saying something, given you’ve already had a year to think things over. As you head to the Capitol Building, you can’t help but feel all your efforts to pass healthcare reform have been in vain, even though you’ve done everything you could. You keep thinking about the promise you made to Hillary when you first ran for office, she’ll be right beside you for the vote, which gives you a little more peace. Still, the choice is yours: you can back out now, or you can move forward with the reform. Pick your move, Bill.

Just two years into your presidency, America is already yearning for even more change. The midterms of ‘94 are fast approaching, and Carville’s sounding the alarm. He says the '93 gubernatorial losses in New Jersey and Virginia weren’t flukes, they were warning shots. To steady the ship, you’ve quietly turned to Dick Morris, the man who helped you win Arkansas back in ’78. ''A third of the country thinks you’re immoral, and another third thinks you’re weak,'' he tells you. ''Now, I can’t fix the first part. But I can fix the second.'' He’s laid out four paths. What’s your move?

Well, this is interesting. Much to the Republicans' chagrin, your performance in the midterms was surprisingly strong, far better than the polls predicted. You've made the House unexpectedly competitive while holding onto the Senate, a situation that bodes well for passing your agenda and gives you the freedom to make some daring moves until ’96. What’s your plan from here?

Well, this is interesting. Much to the Republicans' chagrin, your performance in the midterms was surprisingly strong, far better than the polls predicted. You've made the House unexpectedly competitive while holding onto the Senate, a situation that bodes well for passing your agenda and gives you the freedom to make some daring moves until ’96. What’s your plan from here?

Jesus. You look at your advisors as they analyze the results of the midterms, you can’t help but feel the grim feeling across the room, as they tell you there's no other fitting word, it’s a disaster, as trusty and respected Senators and Governors fall, and staggering majorities for the Republicans establish themselves across the walls of Congress. You have to act, now.

People can't get enough of those photos you have with Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat, pushing for final peace in the Middle East. However, while the Oslo Accord is their impulse, the wounds of war are deep. Too many have already died, and many more still harbor hate for their neighbor. Without the aid of the entire world, poverty and desperation will once more drive a wedge between Israeli and Palestinian.

However, while the Oslo Accord is their impulse, the wounds of war are deep. Too many have already died, and many more still harbor hate for their neighbor. Without the aid of the entire world, poverty and desperation will once more drive a wedge between Israeli and Palestinian.

Since the midterms, the Republicans have carried this smug and cheeky confidence. To Gingrich, Satan himself, the mandate is so overwhelming that he has committed the House to pushing through a set of spending cuts and tax reductions, including cuts to Medicare. And now, they think themselves so grand as to threaten you with a government shutdown if you or your Cabinet overstep on education. This cannot happen.

With total control of both legislative branches, Gingrich, Satan himself, is able to simply power through anything he wants and overrule any veto you may bring. Elected on a platform of youth and change, you now find yourself politically defanged. Some are even calling you a lame duck. After conferring with your Cabinet, the challenge is clear: what can you do now, as the Republicans prepare to dismantle everything that ever helped the people?

You can see it in his face, Gingrich, Satan himself, is frustrated. Without the landslide victory he had worked so hard to achieve, the man who loved to shout and never compromise is now forced to do just that. The question is: how much will you agree to give? After all, you've met with your Cabinet, and they remind you that you're as responsible for the financial well-being of the nation as he is, aren’t you?

If the Israeli–Palestinian peace process is to succeed, each nation that borders Israel and Palestine must have no reason for hostility by the time peace is settled. While Egypt is ready to play ball, Jordan has had many reservations, given their current extreme debt and the sheer unpopularity of Israel in their nation. As their allies, we ought to push them in the right direction so that a peace treaty can be signed.

It’s been a week since that moment with Monica, a young intern you never should’ve gotten involved with, and the world still turns. The staff still moves. The press still smiles. Hillary still stands. That’s what matters. But your thoughts won’t quiet. What were you thinking? How could you cheat on your wife, a woman who’s stood by you for all these years? Don’t play dumb. This isn’t the first time. You’re still tangled up in the Paula Jones case, hoping the Supreme Court doesn’t take it up. Settling might make it all go away, but it would look like guilt. So... what now?

As people begin to look at the numbers, they appear staggering over the past four years. The deficit has always been down, down, down, and down. And suddenly, you cannot quite believe it — you see, for the first time, green numbers next to the chart as it crosses the line back into positive. 1996 is predicted to be a budget surplus!

The Bosnian War has left 101,000 Bosniaks, Croats, and Serbs dead. Despite our aid to Bosnia and Croatia through covert bombing operations, the war shows no sign of ending. But a plan is being formulated by your National Security Advisor, Anthony Lake to promote peace and stability via an Inter-Entity Boundary Line, which would keep the nation unified while separating the various ethnic groups into their own territories. The final decision comes down to you: do you want to pursue negotiations or continue the bombings?

The Bosnian War has left 101,000 Bosniaks, Croats, and Serbs dead. Despite our aid to Bosnia and Croatia through covert bombing operations, the war shows no sign of ending. But a plan is being formulated by your National Security Advisor, Anthony Lake to promote peace and stability via an Inter-Entity Boundary Line, which would keep the nation unified while separating the various ethnic groups into their own territories. The final decision comes down to you: do you want to pursue negotiations or continue the bombings?

You felt as if you shouldn't have woken up from your bed today. The reds, the damn reds are back in Russia! You could have swore Yeltsin was making a mountain of a mole hill, but here it was, right in front of your eyes, the worst possible surprise you could have. Just after the Republican national convention, here they gain the best possible reason as to why they should come back as your term as given Moscow back to the commies! We have to do something!

As the American public begins to transition technologies, a new way of expressing ideologies and opinions has arisen in the form of the Internet. While the Internet is still a relatively new commercial item for many Americans, you see the potential, and sneer at it. The fools say it's a fad, but to many, its rise and eventual domination of our very lives isn’t up for debate. A new tool to be used for your aims. A world where reason prevails over the noise, where the truth drowns out the cynics. But we are so, so far from that. What are your plans to address it?.

After a bitter primary, the aged Kansas Senator Bob Dole briskly walks up the stage stairs to the podium at the RNC. He speaks of restoring trust in government, his honorable service in the Second World War, and a promise to cut income taxes by 15% across the board. ''Let me be the bridge to an America that only the unknowing call myth. Let me be the bridge to a time of tranquility, faith, and confidence in action.'' You feel… guilty about what you have to do. He’s out of his weight class. Out of time. But politics is politics. You’ve got to beat him either way. And with the momentum now building in your favor… how will you channel it?

Jesus Chirst. Pat Buchnan pulled it off. Calling your victory in 1992 ''national suicide’’, he’s accusing you having destroyed this nation and it’s christian values. ''What was immoral and shameful - promiscuity, abortion, homosexuality, suicide — Bill Clinton has made praiseworthy. A dying christian faith creates a dying people, and rest assured we are dying.'' With a smiling and nodding Bill Bennett has his running mate, you understand the importance of this election. Pat Buchanan must be destroyed. The nation can’t survive anything less.

Live from sunny San Diego, the RNC convenes to celebrate its champion. Lamar Alexander approaches the podium, and despite his meek stage presence he boldly proclaims: ''It’s time to send the congressional gerontocracy home,'' he declares, promising ''conservative change.'' He’s selling himself as the fresh face of the GOP, but you know better. This is a man who’s spent decades in the political machine. How do we make sure voters see through the act and send Lamar back to Nashville?

You glare at the TV, unblinking, as King Colin is coronated. With the backing of Bob Dole and George Bush, Powell delivers a stiff speech, arguing that his command in the Gulf has prepared him for the crises you've left abroad and at home. A bone is thrown to the right wing, through a reticent Don Nickles. One thing is certain: this is going to be an ugly brawl.

At home, you watch the RNC with a smirk as the new odd couple takes the stage. Arlen Specter pleads with the ''intolerant right'', likely aimed at a petulant, boycotting Pat Buchanan, to help stop an ''incompetent left.'' That would be you. The desperate appeal is followed by his running mate, Jesse Helms, who accuses you of ''making the nation weaker abroad and at home.'' How will you answer this modern Molotov-Ribbentrop pact?

You're sitting at home, watching this year's RNC in San Diego. Dick Cheney, the former Secretary of Defense and Minority Whip, that damn bulldog has done it. You watch him slowly, and steadily address the crowd: ''A President too busy spinning scandals is too busy to lead — America deserves better.'' You sigh, tempted to turn off the television. Then he gestures toward his running mate: the moderate, strong-jawed Governor of Pennsylvania, Tom Ridge. What a joke. Still, you'll need to respond.

In sunshiny San Diego, pop star-turned-politician Congressman Sonny Bono takes the stage with his signature smile, as his running mate Richard Lugar claps from the stands. He cracks a joke about not having seen crowds this big since the 1970s. He then starts slamming the ''unfair, unfit, and totally out-to-lunch'' tax code, with special venom reserved for the ''barbaric carbon tax, designed by people who’ve never pumped gas in their lives.'' You can’t believe that people actually fell for this bullshit.

My God, he’s done it. Ross Perot has clinched the Republican nomination after a contested primary season and a backroom deal with party elders. Now, with his new running mate, Governor Frank Keating, by his side, the billionaire populist shouts to the delegates in San Diego: ''This country’s broke, folks, and it’s time we fix it. Not next year. Not next decade. Right now. I want to promise the American people: I ain’t beholden to nobody. The politicians, bless their hearts, got us into this mess, and we’ve got to get out.'' How do we stop this circus?

At the RNC in sunny San Diego, Pete Wilson takes the stage. Judd Gregg nods along as he drives home the message on immigration, presenting himself as an outsider ready to shake up Washington. Channeling another California governor, he promises to put an end to your so-called ''culture of entitlement.''. We need to fire back.

Hooray for big money politics — Senator Phil Gramm, the bombastic, and hard right Texan Senator with the massive war chest, prevailed over the less well-funded candidates. Hand in hand with Governor Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin, they weep for a nation filled with crime, red tape and children born out of wedlock and promise to win a final battle against your far left liberalism. How are you going to dispatch dumb and dumber here?

If you hear the words ''flat tax'' again, you just might scream. At the San Diego Convention Centre, Editor-In-Chief Steve Forbes delivers an idiosyncratically stiff in delivery and frenzied in substance speech about special interests, lobbyists and tax codes. Chained to Governor John Engler to hopefully keep him grounded, he's promising a national renewal with a shiny new tax code. How are you going to deal with this single issue candidate?

When you sat down to watch the RNC in San Diego, you couldn't believe your eyes. ''Is that 41?'' you audibly gasped out loud as the former President walked on stage. Alongside his running mate, Governor George Allen of Virginia, Bush rips your administration for ''setting American prestige back 100 years'' and that we ''ought to return to a kinder, gentler tomorrow, and one that we'd want our children to live in.'' It's time to put an old dog to pasture.

It's time to put an old dog to pasture.

After four years of prosperity, the convention, held in the heart of Chicago, felt more like a coronation, as only Lyndon LaRouche's goons had even the barest support to mount a primary challenge. The question remains: how should we set the tone of the convention? Its keynote speech will decide just what we’ll bring to the people for the future. Who should represent the Democratic Party?

In yet another episode of Republican moralizing, Congress has put together a new bill. The “Defense of Marriage Act” trudges on through both houses, making the rounds on FOX as it goes. Most in your party want you to back it, but the activist base watches on in dismay. It’s your move.

Since compromise policy couldn't get anywhere, the question of the rights of the gay community is once more becoming part of the discussion, as their political limbo satisfies no one, not them, and not their opponents. You had promised them that their rights would grow, not shrink, during your term. And now, for many, it feels like it's time for you to make good on that promise, before the election possibly takes away your power to do anything.

Since compromise policy couldn't get anywhere, the question of the rights of the gay community is once more becoming part of the discussion, as their political limbo satisfies no one, not them, and not their opponents. You had promised them that their rights would grow, not shrink, during your term. And now, for many, it feels like it's time for you to make good on that promise, before the election possibly takes away your power to do anything.

You’ve been negotiating with Congress for months, and now it’s sitting in front of you: a bill that, in your own words, will ''end welfare as we know it.'' You’ve vetoed two of these already, but this one has more bipartisan backing. It’s not as draconian as what Gingrich first proposed, but it still makes you uneasy. The pressure is mounting, the country is watching, and Morris has been muttering that no Democrat ever lost votes by looking tough on welfare. Everyone is waiting for your decision.

Welfare is a question you had yet to solve, and now the clock is ticking before election day. While Republican pressure hasn’t been as extreme as expected, given their lack of power in the House, some have been ambitious in what they want to push, while others are determined to make the monster of welfare a somewhat more tamed beast. What gets through goes through you. And somewhere behind it all, Morris keeps murmuring about seizing the center before someone else does.

More terrible news from Iraq. In violation of Bush’s no-fly zones, Saddam Hussein has launched strikes against northern Kurdish militias. The smoke has yet to clear, but your team says an all-out offensive is likely to follow. The National Security Council awaits your reaction.

You get a series of increasingly tense phone calls as you hear Yitzhak Rabin is trying to also settle his struggle with Syria while pushing for peace with Palestine. Everyone is shouting, people on his right calling him over-compromising, people on his left saying he's giving breadcrumbs, Syria calling for immediate withdrawal from the Golan, and many, many more voices screaming. As the second part of Oslo is soon to come, we must have a clear proposal.

You get a series of increasingly tense phone calls as you hear Yitzhak Rabin is trying to also settle his struggle with Syria while pushing for peace with Palestine. Everyone is shouting, people on his right calling him over-compromising, people on his left saying he's giving breadcrumbs, Syria calling for immediate withdrawal from the Golan, and many, many more voices screaming. As the second part of Oslo is soon to come, we must have a clear proposal.

You get a series of increasingly tense phone calls as you hear Yitzhak Rabin is trying to also settle his struggle with Syria while pushing for peace with Palestine. Everyone is shouting, people on his right calling him over-compromising, people on his left saying he's giving breadcrumbs, Syria calling for immediate withdrawal from the Golan, and many, many more voices screaming. As the second part of Oslo is soon to come, we must have a clear proposal.

One month after the signing of Oslo II, you would see on TV the rally he began, hundred of thousands hearing his call for peace at any risk. You were not well versed in Hebrew but you could see in that man the same power in their voice you first saw more than 3 decades ago. Moments after you had cut the feed, you received an urgent message."Mr. President, Yitzhak Rabin has been shot."

Since the Republican Revolution, you’ve been going through a certain amount of soul searching to finally take back the dynamism that had propelled your campaign in 1992. Still, the situation in and out of the country is good, just what should you remind America of to take back control?

The culture war’s strongest warrior has been marching on since the convention, fighting a frantic last stand against crime, invaders, and all manner of degeneracy. What should the campaign make of Pat’s little war on windmills?

When California sneezes, the nation catches a cold. Wilson’s ascendency throughout the primaries has focused the American people on the issue of immigration. Proposition 187 in particular has contrasted your soft image with Wilson’s stronger rhetoric. How do you thread the needle on this issue?

When California sneezes, the nation catches a cold. Wilson’s ascendency throughout the primaries has focused the American people on the issue of immigration. Proposition 187 in particular has contrasted your soft image with Wilson’s stronger rhetoric. How do you thread the needle on this issue?

Since the Republican Revolution, you’ve been going through a certain amount of soul-searching to finally reclaim the dynamism that propelled your campaign in 1992. Despite the sort of celebrity whirlwind surrounding the RNC this year, this is still an election season like any other, and you need to prepare some messaging. What do you think?

Despite the fact that you had, all things considered, a pretty good midterm in 1994, the GOP is still swinging, and swinging hard. You’ve been forced to spend a lot of time, both at the White House and on the campaign trail, defending your initiatives, beliefs, and record from wild, increasingly desperate attacks by Newt Gingrich, who leads a slim majority, and other Republicans, Cheney among them. It’s time to hit back, and find a message, Slick.

Phil Gramm may be the one man with a record as... gray... as your own. To compensate, he’s making every appeal possible to the Religious Right, constant appearances with Jerry Falwell, vague allusions to morality, and bold promises to repeal Roe v. Wade. This would all be typical midterm rhetoric, except he’s not attacking you. Still, you’re not about to let him set the conversation. What’s the plan?

‘’Inattentive, inactive and indecisive, that’s the Clinton foreign policy in three words.’’ Senator Specter, trying to walk the line between the general base and ensuring his troops turn out, is trying to make foreign policy the issue of the day. With the world watching and America’s role constantly evolving, how will you defend the Clinton Doctrine?

Lamar’s record has brought a typically de-emphasized type of policy to the forefront of the election — education policy. From his opposition of school choice, to his kickback filled time as Bush’s Secretary of Education, to his current hard right turn, this is certainly an issue you have the upper hand on. How should you press your advantage?

Lamar’s record has brought a typically de-emphasized type of policy to the forefront of the election – education policy. From his opposition of school choice, to his kickback filled time as Bush’s Secretary of Education, to his current hard right turn, this is certainly an issue you have the upper hand on. How should you press your advantage?

Some might say Powell is steely. You say he’s stiff. But when he speaks, people listen, and right now, he’s saying we need competent leadership. With scandals everywhere and a party ready to revolt, Powell promises to be the quietly competent leader you could never be. You need to show the public everything you’ve done, teach them how you helped them.

Through his worship of the flat tax as a golden calf, Forbes has unintentionally stumbled onto an issue with some salience — transparency and reform in government. While he uses Congressional and Judicial term limits and attacks on Washington insiders to supplant his true love, the flat tax, your stat men are showing his points are resonating. How will we adapt?

Once more, You and Bush find yourself battling on how to make the economy work. While George has his albatross, being the fact that the economy was truly awful in his own term, he's claiming the ringing of how the economy is doing better is actually thanks to the Republicans input, rather than the Democrats own. In short, it became a simple zinger. "The Republicans gather, the Democrats Spend.", it's almost a bold face lie, and yet it's effective.

It's like we're in the 1980's again. Russia and its new renewed ambitions pushing for the reforming of the union between sister republics in Belarus and Kazakhstan, its rapprochement to China and support for the Regime of Milosevic in Yugoslavia are the only things people are talking about. No one really knows how to deal with it. The Republicans are bringing the man of the CIA that stood both firm and with an open palm to Gorbachev, how could you present yourself as the better candidate?

Ross Perot's successful siege of the Republican Party has completely upended the race. Just a few weeks ago, it was widely assumed some generic conseus Republican would secure the nomination at a contested convention, not the billionaire warrior. The latest polls show you riding a nice wave, and your numbers are improving. But the biggest question remains: what should our message be heading into the fall?

Bob Dole’s a really easy target. He’s known to all and yet loved by nearly nobody. He’s been in Washington longer than most voters have been alive, and while there’s respect for his service, there’s a lot of baggage there too. He’s the champion of the GOP in a confused after-Reagan haze. No message, no momentum, no magic. If we’re gonna beat him clean, you’ll need something sharp, something that shatters the whole façade.

So far, you’ve been mostly reactive to Pat Buchanan’s accusations of being a drug-addicted, womanizing pedophile, that’s going to change. You smirk while reading the files for planned attacks, flipping through the pages with a practiced ease; which one is your favorite?

Lamar Alexander is a blank canvas. Relatively unknown nationally, despite heading a presidential ticket, you can make him out to be whatever you want, the next Goldwater, or Rockefeller’s ineffectual protégé. How should we define the flannel wearing bozo?

The rise of Sonny Bono was nominally sparked by your carbon tax, but it doesn't take an expert to see he's tapping into something deeper — a cocktail of conservative discontent, celebrity appeal, and anti-establishment mood. Your campaign has assembled document after document detailing his scandals and inconsistencies, most of them already dragged out by his Republican rivals during the long, bitter primary slog. The press barely blinked then, but this is the big-time now. How do you want to stop this guy?

Dick Cheney is eager to hammer you on character, dragging Hillary and the whole administration with it. But unlike most Republicans who try it, Secretary Cheney has a clean record. At least personally. Still, your team found one thing: his eldest daughter. She’s a lesbian. D.C. insiders know. A few of his nuttier primary opponents even floated it. But it hasn’t quite hit the public square, not yet, anyway. Do you want to go there?

Pete Wilson would be Lee Atwater’s wet dream if he was in your shoes. There are the obvious points of attack – his broken promise to not run for President being the most obvious, but dig a little deeper, and you’ll find plenty more to work with. The question is, which angle do you take?

Senator Gramm was brave to run for office, to say the least, between funding porn, helping drug dealers walk free, and his cozy ties to big-money donors, it’s a wonder he had the gall to try. Not that you have much room to judge. Still, he’s a soft target. Where to hit?

You've fought tough opponents before, but Arlen Specter is something different. No scandals, moderate viewpoints, and impeccable conduct on the trail, keeping the campaign on the issues even if his supporters echo the typical slander. It’s so noxious, eating away at you. Specter needs to learn the reality of politics, the hard way. Where to hit, and how hard?

Powell hasn’t been directly engaging in personal attacks, letting Nickles carry his water while he calmly and reasonably explains how you’ve failed on national security. The passive-aggressiveness, the cowardice, is this the war hero? Time to try and strike back.

Steve Forbes is such an odd little man. A populist millionaire, an outsider that touts a standard insider platform, a single issue candidate touting a single issue that fires up no one — all the while being a profoundly awkward man. Weighing up the options to attack him, you almost feel bad for him.

Last time, you had a few glaring spots you could keep on bashing. Dan Quayle, the economy, the usual. However today, since your the incumbent and Bush made a way better VP pick in George Allen, we need to find which bullet in which gun will kill the target as Bush won't throw any of his pushes to take you down. Where do you strike?

Last time, you had a few glaring spots you could keep on bashing. Dan Quayle, the economy, the usual. However today, since your the incumbent and Bush made a way better VP pick in George Allen, we need to find which bullet in which gun will kill the target as Bush won't throw any of his pushes to take you down. Where do you strike?

Ross Perot, even back in 1992, was reluctant to wade into character attacks. But since entering Republican politics, he’s been more than willing to shout into microphones, denouncing your ethics: ''I am sick and tired of the lying, shady, slick and donor-poisoned Democrat President!'' Our team has drafted a few ideas for a comeback, but it’s your call whether to greenlight one. What do you say?

You’ve talked a lot about the issues that affect the nation broadly, but don’t lose sight of the states that’ll actually decide this election. No matter what Dole throws at us, you’ll have to finish strong where it counts, Ohio, Missouri, Florida, Pennsylvania. That’s where the race is won or lost. Do you have a plan in mind?

If there’s something that can be said for Pat Buchanan’s wild campaign, it’s an exceptionally electorally efficient one. Memories of snobs like Jerry Brown fill your mind while you watch Pat lambast you as a ‘’free traitor’’ in Ohio. How will you adapt?

If Lamar poses any problem for you, it’s that he shares an electoral base in the beautiful Upper South. As he modestly roams the region, we’ve got ample time to plan a multi-state tour of our own. Is there any region you’d like to focus on to regain ground?

As of late, you've been focusing on the big picture, but it’s clear Sonny Bono is pin-pointing his campaign efforts, and focusing on a few select regions. If you want to beat him, you’ll have to make your own mark across the map. What regions in particular do you want to commit your focus to?

You’ve been talking to packed union halls, suburban rec centers, small-town school gyms, Black churches, VFW halls, police groups, classrooms—anyone, anywhere who’ll have you. Just running down the clock. But Dick Cheney’s not running that kind of race. He’s quiet, methodical, brutal. His people have zeroed in on a hard, narrow path: Missouri, Tennessee, Colorado, Ohio. No one else matters. So, what’s your next move?

The Wilson campaign has been doing remarkably well across the board, as the nation listens to his biting criticisms of your record on immigration, foreign policy, and the economy. Is there any region you’d like to focus on to regain ground?

The Solid South has never been so slippery — while you made inroads compared to Dukakis, of course, Gramm is a real Texan with deep roots and a direct line to Jerry Falwell. Your advisors are bickering in front of you, each pushing a different strategy. Which is it?

Senator Arlen Specter, the darling of the urban East. With Senator Al D’Amato at his side, Specter’s mix of moderate social views, pro-business economics, and a tough-on-crime stance is proving potent in these cities. How do we stop the bleeding before it’s too late?

It eats away at you, reading the polls. There’s a real chance to show up Jimmy Carter and really sweep the South one last time for the Democrats. But it’s obvious why there’s such a chance, you can pretend it’s abortion and affirmative action all you like, but you know why. All your cynical instincts are telling you to push this forward — will you?

Forbes is a dollar store Perot, down to having far less money than the tech magnate. But what he lacks in charisma and money he makes up for in passion, furiously hitting rally after rally while Perot runs a lackadaisical, disinterested campaign. In Perot’s strongest areas, Forbes seems ready to excel. How will you adapt?

You’ve talked about the issues that affect the nation more widely, but don't forget, there's still work needed on the states that decide the election. Whatever Bush’s going to do, we’ll have to strike our own where it matters.

You’re in Hartford, Connecticut. To your right stands Senator Dole—the poor old soul. As he wraps up his opening statement, you wonder: why did he run? Doesn’t he see the polls? This has to be one of the most lopsided races in recent memory, and he’s the one taking the punches for all to see. Maybe it doesn’t matter to him. Maybe he sees something you don’t. But if that’s the case, you’ve got to stop him here. For his own good, and for the country’s, send him into retirement.

You and Lamar stand across from each other – San Diego is friendly territory for you at this point, but Lamar clearly feels like he’s behind enemy lines. You enter this debate the favorite, and Lamar’s speaking style may make this debate fatal for his chances. How’re we bringing this election home tonight, Bill?

As you stand behind the podium in the Bushnell Center, the massive insult of implying you and Buchanan are alike really sinks in. He keeps sending you these little glares while Jim Lehrer reads out the rules, you deny him even a glance. What has your prep been focused on?

As you stand behind the podium in the Bushnell Center, the massive insult of implying you and Buchanan are alike really sinks in. He keeps sending you these little glares while Jim Lehrer reads out the rules, you deny him even a glance. What has your prep been focused on?

You and Wilson stand across from each other—San Diego may be his home, but it’s your crowd. You shake hands respectfully and meet his empty, beady eyes for a moment before the debate begins. Wilson’s got the momentum, spinning your successes as inadequate and your failures as glaring. How’re you going to shake that narrative, Slick?

For a media guy, Forbes sure is an unusual personality. You observe him practicing gesticulation while Jim Leher reads the rules of the debate, and trying to hide a smirk. By most people’s expectations, this will be a stomp. But that means Forbes will be benefiting from low expectations. Tread carefully, Slick — a strong Forbes performance could be a fiasco.

By most people’s expectations, this will be a stomp. But that means Forbes will be benefiting from low expectations. Tread carefully, Slick — a strong Forbes performance could be a fiasco.

Senator Gramm shakes your hand with a firm squeeze, locking eyes with you in a silent challenge as Jim Lehrer explains the rules. But as soon as the cameras roll, his expression shifts to a practiced grin, smoothly launching into why your foreign and domestic policies have been a total failure. It’s clear, he wants a fight, but he wants it clean. Will you indulge?

An attorney versus an attorney. As you skim your debate notes under the sweltering lights of the Bushnell Center, a wave of nostalgia hits, a reminder of past battles fought and won. The moment is short-lived, interrupted as Arlen Specter strides over, extending his hand. A brief, firm shake, then back to your notes. Time to focus. What’s the best way to hit Specter tonight?

These past four years, you’ve met so many world leaders, titans of industry, and military experts that you’re awed by few. But the way Powell saunters in, a stony gaze commanding the room, you’re man enough to admit you’re nervous. A lot more than during the ‘92 debates. What’s your tactic to handle him?

It’s time to face Bush head to head, without Perot to steal the show. When you get there, you see him. He's old, creaky, yet the most determined you've seen him. You can tell he's learned from his mistakes. He didn't even bring his watch. It's almost time, what are you gonna focus on?

It’s time to face Bush head to head, without Perot to steal the show. When you get there, you see him. He's old, creaky, yet the most determined you've seen him. You can tell he's learned from his mistakes. He didn't even bring his watch. It's almost time, what are you gonna focus on?

You're in Las Vegas, Nevada, on the debate stage, after many hours spent preparing with your team. To your right is the perpetually grinning Sonny Bono, the Congressman seems to be dripping with nervous humor. He plays it off well, regardless, and he's wrapping up his opening statement. You look at the moderator for a second, and he nods to you, ''Mr. President?'' It's your turn, Slick.

You're in Athens, Georgia, on the debate stage. It's your first of the cycle, and to your right stands Secretary Dick Cheney, cool as a cucumber, as per usual. For a moment, you nearly drift off. The egghead drones on and on about something or other, his voice sounds like static. You blink. And just like that, it's your turn, Slick.

You're in Cleveland, Ohio, under the hot lights of the presidential debate stage. To your right stands the other man who faced Bush four years ago, Ross Perot. He stands stiff, straight as an arrow, eyes narrowed like he's staring down death. ''Let me break it down for you—if Washington could balance a lemonade stand, we wouldn’t be here tonight,'' he snaps, before launching into more of his usual ranting. The moderator turns. ''Mr. President?'' It’s your turn, Slick.

As the memory of Yitzhak's death is still fresh in the people's memories, and as the leading coalition was barely holding on without their leader, the new Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, called for early elections. Many think it will be a tough race, as the right is fighting as one under the young Benjamin Netanyahu, who has his own plan for peace with Palestine. Only time will tell who wins.

It’s the morning of November 4th, 1996. You can’t stop thinking about how far you’ve come since 1978. Once a bright, young Attorney General hoping to become your state’s governor—now, you’re running for re-election as President, standing in the very spot 41 stood when he lost to you. You’ve imagined the relief of reliving that winning feeling, but the sting of loss, the tears you shed back in 1980, still lingers. With that in mind, what will be your final message to the American people as they head to the polls tomorrow?
Four more years. An honor never awarded to a Democrat since FDR. The world is your oyster

Despite your recent victory a few months ago, you’ve barely made a dent in Gingrich’s coalition. Both the Senate and House remain under his rule. Now, you’ve arrived at the House chamber to deliver your first State of the Union address, to a partisan Congress that’s hardly changed since your first term, and that’s fought you tooth and nail, on everything, everywhere. What could you possibly say to bring them across the aisle?

They finally got something to stick. Not the deals, not the calls, not the meetings. Not the things that would really matter. Just this. A smudge. A spectacle. How fitting. The American people don’t see the strings — just the hand waving on stage. Tripp, Starr, those bastards. Always waiting for the crack. But cracks can be sealed. Now, it’s time to play defense. You’re sure as hell gonna need it, Slick.

At night, when you finally get a chance to sit down and watch some TV with Hillary, and despite your best efforts to focus on the onscreen drama, she’s eager to tell you about her attempts to sway Congress in favor of her healthcare reform. She vents about ''not being treated like the politician she is'' or something along those lines, insisting that her efforts are going well. Obviously, you don’t entirely believe her, but you decide to trust your wife. Then she asks for your input on who to work with. You know exactly what to do, Slick.

After a month, which has felt like a millennia since you've entered office, Ted can finally get back to you on the healthcare. He informs your he's been working his ass on the initiative, trying to get droves of Democrats on board. He insures you it can be done, but it's going to take a herculean swing to get it done. He asks you to give him suggestions for the reform getting passed, and you know just what to do.

You're in the Oval Office, doing paperwork, when Mitchell and Foley stride into the room to discuss healthcare reform. They inform you of their plans: mandating insurance, forcing businesses to provide coverage for employees, and subsidizing those on the short end of the stick. It’s a rather moderate proposal, but they’re confident this is what can be passed with relative ease. You, staying true to Hillary’s dream, feel this proposal is too watered down to be called real ''reform.'' But at the same time, there’s the matter of getting something passed. They ask for your opinion, but they’ve already made it clear what they want to do. But you know best, don’t you, Slick?

The healthcare plan has finally been unveiled, and it's a disaster. You should have known letting the pharmaceutical corporations have a say was a bad idea. They simply took almost all the talking points from the HEART Act, and slapped on more tax breaks for healthcare businesses. You're enraged, you're not letting this see the house floor, so you might as well kill it before it gets the chance.

You woke up this morning feeling more stressed than ever at this job-and that’s saying something, given you’ve already had a year to think things over. As you head to the Capitol Building, you can’t help but feel all your efforts to pass healthcare reform have been in vain, even though you’ve done everything you could. You keep thinking about the promise you made to Hillary when you first ran for office, she’ll be right beside you for the vote, which gives you a little more peace. Still, the choice is yours: you can back out now, or you can move forward with the reform. Pick your move, Bill.

Just a few years ago, the U.S. and Russia were mortal enemies, teetering on the edge of mutual destruction. Now, at what some are calling ''the End of History,'' your friendship with Boris Yeltsin is so close that critics and supporters alike compare it to a love affair. Standing here in the Kremlin, with Russia’s fragile democracy hanging in the balance, and its economy lurching through a painful transition, what will you prioritize in these negotiations?
