Now, at what some are calling ''the End of History,'' your friendship with Boris Yeltsin is so close that critics and supporters alike compare it to a love affair. Standing here in the Kremlin, with Russia’s fragile democracy hanging in the balance, and its economy lurching through a painful transition, what will you prioritize in these negotiations?

Well, we’ve got some bad news. It’s a disaster. The Republicans have obtained sweeping gains in the midterms, to a level where several big name Democrats, including Speaker Foley, were unable to win re-election, as the election was a sweeping rebuke of your presidency, as even the heir-apparent to the Speakership, Newt Gingrich, dubbing this a ''Republican Revolution.'' You’ve got to do some damage control here.

At this point, it feels like every day brings another mess you’ve inherited from the Bush administration. No wonder you kicked his ass so badly. Crime skyrocketed under Reagan and only got worse under 41, hitting an all-time high merely three years ago. You made it clear to Reno from day one that something had to be done, and now, after months of back-and-forth, she’s pushing for reform. You’re finally weighing your options. What’s your move?

At this point, it feels like every day brings another mess you’ve inherited from the Bush administration. No wonder you kicked his ass so badly. Crime skyrocketed under Reagan and only got worse under 41, hitting an all-time high merely three years ago. You made it clear to Reno from day one that something had to be done, and now, after months of back-and-forth, she’s pushing for reform. You’re finally weighing your options. What’s your move?

Well, this is interesting. Much to the Republicans' chagrin, your performance in the midterms was surprisingly strong, far better than the polls predicted. You've made the House unexpectedly competitive while holding onto the Senate, a situation that bodes well for passing your agenda and gives you the freedom to make some daring moves until ’96. What’s your plan from here?

Well, this is interesting. Much to the Republicans' chagrin, your performance in the midterms was surprisingly strong, far better than the polls predicted. You've made the House unexpectedly competitive while holding onto the Senate, a situation that bodes well for passing your agenda and gives you the freedom to make some daring moves until ’96. What’s your plan from here?

Jesus. You look at your advisors as they analyze the results of the midterms, you can’t help but feel the grim feeling across the room, as they tell you there's no other fitting word, it’s a disaster, as trusty and respected Senators and Governors fall, and staggering majorities for the Republicans establish themselves across the walls of Congress. You have to act, now.

In yet another episode of Republican moralizing, Congress has put together a new bill. The “Defense of Marriage Act” trudges on through both houses, making the rounds on FOX as it goes. Most in your party want you to back it, but the activist base watches on in dismay. It’s your move.

Since compromise policy couldn't get anywhere, the question of the rights of the gay community is once more becoming part of the discussion, as their political limbo satisfies no one, not them, and not their opponents. You had promised them that their rights would grow, not shrink, during your term. And now, for many, it feels like it's time for you to make good on that promise, before the election possibly takes away your power to do anything.

Since compromise policy couldn't get anywhere, the question of the rights of the gay community is once more becoming part of the discussion, as their political limbo satisfies no one, not them, and not their opponents. You had promised them that their rights would grow, not shrink, during your term. And now, for many, it feels like it's time for you to make good on that promise, before the election possibly takes away your power to do anything.

You’ve been negotiating with Congress for months, and now it’s sitting in front of you: a bill that, in your own words, will ''end welfare as we know it.'' You’ve vetoed two of these already, but this one has more bipartisan backing. It’s not as draconian as what Gingrich first proposed, but it still makes you uneasy. The pressure is mounting, the country is watching, and Morris has been muttering that no Democrat ever lost votes by looking tough on welfare. Everyone is waiting for your decision.

Welfare is a question you had yet to solve, and now the clock is ticking before election day. While Republican pressure hasn’t been as extreme as expected, given their lack of power in the House, some have been ambitious in what they want to push, while others are determined to make the monster of welfare a somewhat more tamed beast. What gets through goes through you. And somewhere behind it all, Morris keeps murmuring about seizing the center before someone else does.

After a bitter primary, the aged Kansas Senator Bob Dole briskly walks up the stage stairs to the podium at the RNC. He speaks of restoring trust in government, his honorable service in the Second World War, and a promise to cut income taxes by 15% across the board. ''Let me be the bridge to an America that only the unknowing call myth. Let me be the bridge to a time of tranquility, faith, and confidence in action.'' You feel… guilty about what you have to do. He’s out of his weight class. Out of time. But politics is politics. You’ve got to beat him either way. And with the momentum now building in your favor… how will you channel it?

Jesus Chirst. Pat Buchnan pulled it off. Calling your victory in 1992 ''national suicide’’, he’s accusing you having destroyed this nation and it’s christian values. ''What was immoral and shameful - promiscuity, abortion, homosexuality, suicide — Bill Clinton has made praiseworthy. A dying christian faith creates a dying people, and rest assured we are dying.'' With a smiling and nodding Bill Bennett has his running mate, you understand the importance of this election. Pat Buchanan must be destroyed. The nation can’t survive anything less.

Live from sunny San Diego, the RNC convenes to celebrate its champion. Lamar Alexander approaches the podium, and despite his meek stage presence he boldly proclaims: ''It’s time to send the congressional gerontocracy home,'' he declares, promising ''conservative change.'' He’s selling himself as the fresh face of the GOP, but you know better. This is a man who’s spent decades in the political machine. How do we make sure voters see through the act and send Lamar back to Nashville?

You glare at the TV, unblinking, as King Colin is coronated. With the backing of Bob Dole and George Bush, Powell delivers a stiff speech, arguing that his command in the Gulf has prepared him for the crises you've left abroad and at home. A bone is thrown to the right wing, through a reticent Don Nickles. One thing is certain: this is going to be an ugly brawl.

At home, you watch the RNC with a smirk as the new odd couple takes the stage. Arlen Specter pleads with the ''intolerant right'', likely aimed at a petulant, boycotting Pat Buchanan, to help stop an ''incompetent left.'' That would be you. The desperate appeal is followed by his running mate, Jesse Helms, who accuses you of ''making the nation weaker abroad and at home.'' How will you answer this modern Molotov-Ribbentrop pact?

You're sitting at home, watching this year's RNC in San Diego. Dick Cheney, the former Secretary of Defense and Minority Whip, that damn bulldog has done it. You watch him slowly, and steadily address the crowd: ''A President too busy spinning scandals is too busy to lead — America deserves better.'' You sigh, tempted to turn off the television. Then he gestures toward his running mate: the moderate, strong-jawed Governor of Pennsylvania, Tom Ridge. What a joke. Still, you'll need to respond.

In sunshiny San Diego, pop star-turned-politician Congressman Sonny Bono takes the stage with his signature smile, as his running mate Richard Lugar claps from the stands. He cracks a joke about not having seen crowds this big since the 1970s. He then starts slamming the ''unfair, unfit, and totally out-to-lunch'' tax code, with special venom reserved for the ''barbaric carbon tax, designed by people who’ve never pumped gas in their lives.'' You can’t believe that people actually fell for this bullshit.

Since the Republican Revolution, you’ve been going through a certain amount of soul-searching to finally reclaim the dynamism that propelled your campaign in 1992. Despite the sort of celebrity whirlwind surrounding the RNC this year, this is still an election season like any other, and you need to prepare some messaging. What do you think?

The rise of Sonny Bono was nominally sparked by your carbon tax, but it doesn't take an expert to see he's tapping into something deeper — a cocktail of conservative discontent, celebrity appeal, and anti-establishment mood. Your campaign has assembled document after document detailing his scandals and inconsistencies, most of them already dragged out by his Republican rivals during the long, bitter primary slog. The press barely blinked then, but this is the big-time now. How do you want to stop this guy?

As of late, you've been focusing on the big picture, but it’s clear Sonny Bono is pin-pointing his campaign efforts, and focusing on a few select regions. If you want to beat him, you’ll have to make your own mark across the map. What regions in particular do you want to commit your focus to?

You’ve been talking to packed union halls, suburban rec centers, small-town school gyms, Black churches, VFW halls, police groups, classrooms—anyone, anywhere who’ll have you. Just running down the clock. But Dick Cheney’s not running that kind of race. He’s quiet, methodical, brutal. His people have zeroed in on a hard, narrow path: Missouri, Tennessee, Colorado, Ohio. No one else matters. So, what’s your next move?

You're in Las Vegas, Nevada, on the debate stage, after many hours spent preparing with your team. To your right is the perpetually grinning Sonny Bono, the Congressman seems to be dripping with nervous humor. He plays it off well, regardless, and he's wrapping up his opening statement. You look at the moderator for a second, and he nods to you, ''Mr. President?'' It's your turn, Slick.

At the RNC in sunny San Diego, Pete Wilson takes the stage. Judd Gregg nods along as he drives home the message on immigration, presenting himself as an outsider ready to shake up Washington. Channeling another California governor, he promises to put an end to your so-called ''culture of entitlement.''. We need to fire back.

Hooray for big money politics — Senator Phil Gramm, the bombastic, and hard right Texan Senator with the massive war chest, prevailed over the less well-funded candidates. Hand in hand with Governor Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin, they weep for a nation filled with crime, red tape and children born out of wedlock and promise to win a final battle against your far left liberalism. How are you going to dispatch dumb and dumber here?

If you hear the words ''flat tax'' again, you just might scream. At the San Diego Convention Centre, Editor-In-Chief Steve Forbes delivers an idiosyncratically stiff in delivery and frenzied in substance speech about special interests, lobbyists and tax codes. Chained to Governor John Engler to hopefully keep him grounded, he's promising a national renewal with a shiny new tax code. How are you going to deal with this single issue candidate?

When you sat down to watch the RNC in San Diego, you couldn't believe your eyes. ''Is that 41?'' you audibly gasped out loud as the former President walked on stage. Alongside his running mate, Governor George Allen of Virginia, Bush rips your administration for ''setting American prestige back 100 years'' and that we ''ought to return to a kinder, gentler tomorrow, and one that we'd want our children to live in.'' It's time to put an old dog to pasture.

It's time to put an old dog to pasture.

After four years of prosperity, the convention, held in the heart of Chicago, felt more like a coronation, as only Lyndon LaRouche's goons had even the barest support to mount a primary challenge. The question remains: how should we set the tone of the convention? Its keynote speech will decide just what we’ll bring to the people for the future. Who should represent the Democratic Party?

The question remains: how should we set the tone of the convention? Its keynote speech will decide just what we’ll bring to the people for the future. Who should represent the Democratic Party?

The question remains: how should we set the tone of the convention? Its keynote speech will decide just what we’ll bring to the people for the future. Who should represent the Democratic Party?

The question remains: how should we set the tone of the convention? Its keynote speech will decide just what we’ll bring to the people for the future. Who should represent the Democratic Party?

The question remains: how should we set the tone of the convention? Its keynote speech will decide just what we’ll bring to the people for the future. Who should represent the Democratic Party?

Since the Republican Revolution, you’ve been going through a certain amount of soul searching to finally take back the dynamism that had propelled your campaign in 1992. Still, the situation in and out of the country is good, just what should you remind America of to take back control?

Despite the fact that you had, all things considered, a pretty good midterm in 1994, the GOP is still swinging, and swinging hard. You’ve been forced to spend a lot of time, both at the White House and on the campaign trail, defending your initiatives, beliefs, and record from wild, increasingly desperate attacks by Newt Gingrich, who leads a slim majority, and other Republicans, Cheney among them. It’s time to hit back, and find a message, Slick.

Dick Cheney is eager to hammer you on character, dragging Hillary and the whole administration with it. But unlike most Republicans who try it, Secretary Cheney has a clean record. At least personally. Still, your team found one thing: his eldest daughter. She’s a lesbian. D.C. insiders know. A few of his nuttier primary opponents even floated it. But it hasn’t quite hit the public square, not yet, anyway. Do you want to go there?

Bob Dole’s a really easy target. He’s known to all and yet loved by nearly nobody. He’s been in Washington longer than most voters have been alive, and while there’s respect for his service, there’s a lot of baggage there too. He’s the champion of the GOP in a confused after-Reagan haze. No message, no momentum, no magic. If we’re gonna beat him clean, you’ll need something sharp, something that shatters the whole façade.

You’ve talked a lot about the issues that affect the nation broadly, but don’t lose sight of the states that’ll actually decide this election. No matter what Dole throws at us, you’ll have to finish strong where it counts, Ohio, Missouri, Florida, Pennsylvania. That’s where the race is won or lost. Do you have a plan in mind?

The culture war’s strongest warrior has been marching on since the convention, fighting a frantic last stand against crime, invaders, and all manner of degeneracy. What should the campaign make of Pat’s little war on windmills?

So far, you’ve been mostly reactive to Pat Buchanan’s accusations of being a drug-addicted, womanizing pedophile, that’s going to change. You smirk while reading the files for planned attacks, flipping through the pages with a practiced ease; which one is your favorite?

If there’s something that can be said for Pat Buchanan’s wild campaign, it’s an exceptionally electorally efficient one. Memories of snobs like Jerry Brown fill your mind while you watch Pat lambast you as a ‘’free traitor’’ in Ohio. How will you adapt?

When California sneezes, the nation catches a cold. Wilson’s ascendency throughout the primaries has focused the American people on the issue of immigration. Proposition 187 in particular has contrasted your soft image with Wilson’s stronger rhetoric. How do you thread the needle on this issue?

When California sneezes, the nation catches a cold. Wilson’s ascendency throughout the primaries has focused the American people on the issue of immigration. Proposition 187 in particular has contrasted your soft image with Wilson’s stronger rhetoric. How do you thread the needle on this issue?

Pete Wilson would be Lee Atwater’s wet dream if he was in your shoes. There are the obvious points of attack – his broken promise to not run for President being the most obvious, but dig a little deeper, and you’ll find plenty more to work with. The question is, which angle do you take?

The Wilson campaign has been doing remarkably well across the board, as the nation listens to his biting criticisms of your record on immigration, foreign policy, and the economy. Is there any region you’d like to focus on to regain ground?

Phil Gramm may be the one man with a record as... gray... as your own. To compensate, he’s making every appeal possible to the Religious Right, constant appearances with Jerry Falwell, vague allusions to morality, and bold promises to repeal Roe v. Wade. This would all be typical midterm rhetoric, except he’s not attacking you. Still, you’re not about to let him set the conversation. What’s the plan?

Senator Gramm was brave to run for office, to say the least, between funding porn, helping drug dealers walk free, and his cozy ties to big-money donors, it’s a wonder he had the gall to try. Not that you have much room to judge. Still, he’s a soft target. Where to hit?

The Solid South has never been so slippery — while you made inroads compared to Dukakis, of course, Gramm is a real Texan with deep roots and a direct line to Jerry Falwell. Your advisors are bickering in front of you, each pushing a different strategy. Which is it?

‘’Inattentive, inactive and indecisive, that’s the Clinton foreign policy in three words.’’ Senator Specter, trying to walk the line between the general base and ensuring his troops turn out, is trying to make foreign policy the issue of the day. With the world watching and America’s role constantly evolving, how will you defend the Clinton Doctrine?

You've fought tough opponents before, but Arlen Specter is something different. No scandals, moderate viewpoints, and impeccable conduct on the trail, keeping the campaign on the issues even if his supporters echo the typical slander. It’s so noxious, eating away at you. Specter needs to learn the reality of politics, the hard way. Where to hit, and how hard?

Senator Arlen Specter, the darling of the urban East. With Senator Al D’Amato at his side, Specter’s mix of moderate social views, pro-business economics, and a tough-on-crime stance is proving potent in these cities. How do we stop the bleeding before it’s too late?

Lamar’s record has brought a typically de-emphasized type of policy to the forefront of the election — education policy. From his opposition of school choice, to his kickback filled time as Bush’s Secretary of Education, to his current hard right turn, this is certainly an issue you have the upper hand on. How should you press your advantage?

Lamar’s record has brought a typically de-emphasized type of policy to the forefront of the election – education policy. From his opposition of school choice, to his kickback filled time as Bush’s Secretary of Education, to his current hard right turn, this is certainly an issue you have the upper hand on. How should you press your advantage?

Lamar Alexander is a blank canvas. Relatively unknown nationally, despite heading a presidential ticket, you can make him out to be whatever you want, the next Goldwater, or Rockefeller’s ineffectual protégé. How should we define the flannel wearing bozo?

If Lamar poses any problem for you, it’s that he shares an electoral base in the beautiful Upper South. As he modestly roams the region, we’ve got ample time to plan a multi-state tour of our own. Is there any region you’d like to focus on to regain ground?

Some might say Powell is steely. You say he’s stiff. But when he speaks, people listen, and right now, he’s saying we need competent leadership. With scandals everywhere and a party ready to revolt, Powell promises to be the quietly competent leader you could never be. You need to show the public everything you’ve done, teach them how you helped them.

Powell hasn’t been directly engaging in personal attacks, letting Nickles carry his water while he calmly and reasonably explains how you’ve failed on national security. The passive-aggressiveness, the cowardice, is this the war hero? Time to try and strike back.

It eats away at you, reading the polls. There’s a real chance to show up Jimmy Carter and really sweep the South one last time for the Democrats. But it’s obvious why there’s such a chance, you can pretend it’s abortion and affirmative action all you like, but you know why. All your cynical instincts are telling you to push this forward — will you?

Through his worship of the flat tax as a golden calf, Forbes has unintentionally stumbled onto an issue with some salience — transparency and reform in government. While he uses Congressional and Judicial term limits and attacks on Washington insiders to supplant his true love, the flat tax, your stat men are showing his points are resonating. How will we adapt?

Steve Forbes is such an odd little man. A populist millionaire, an outsider that touts a standard insider platform, a single issue candidate touting a single issue that fires up no one — all the while being a profoundly awkward man. Weighing up the options to attack him, you almost feel bad for him.

Forbes is a dollar store Perot, down to having far less money than the tech magnate. But what he lacks in charisma and money he makes up for in passion, furiously hitting rally after rally while Perot runs a lackadaisical, disinterested campaign. In Perot’s strongest areas, Forbes seems ready to excel. How will you adapt?

Once more, You and Bush find yourself battling on how to make the economy work. While George has his albatross, being the fact that the economy was truly awful in his own term, he's claiming the ringing of how the economy is doing better is actually thanks to the Republicans input, rather than the Democrats own. In short, it became a simple zinger. "The Republicans gather, the Democrats Spend.", it's almost a bold face lie, and yet it's effective.

It's like we're in the 1980's again. Russia and its new renewed ambitions pushing for the reforming of the union between sister republics in Belarus and Kazakhstan, its rapprochement to China and support for the Regime of Milosevic in Yugoslavia are the only things people are talking about. No one really knows how to deal with it. The Republicans are bringing the man of the CIA that stood both firm and with an open palm to Gorbachev, how could you present yourself as the better candidate?

Last time, you had a few glaring spots you could keep on bashing. Dan Quayle, the economy, the usual. However today, since your the incumbent and Bush made a way better VP pick in George Allen, we need to find which bullet in which gun will kill the target as Bush won't throw any of his pushes to take you down. Where do you strike?

Last time, you had a few glaring spots you could keep on bashing. Dan Quayle, the economy, the usual. However today, since your the incumbent and Bush made a way better VP pick in George Allen, we need to find which bullet in which gun will kill the target as Bush won't throw any of his pushes to take you down. Where do you strike?

While you’ve been focusing on your messaging, general strategy, and delivering what many see as tightly prepared speeches and polished events, Ross Perot’s been whipping up a wild fire, filling up auditoriums, flooding the airwaves, and talking straight to working-class voters. The businessman seems to think he can flip a good chunk of those union-heavy Midwestern states that still feel burned over NAFTA. How are you going to counter this?

You’ve talked about the issues that affect the nation more widely, but don't forget, there's still work needed on the states that decide the election. Whatever Bush’s going to do, we’ll have to strike our own where it matters.

You felt as if you shouldn't have woken up from your bed today. The reds, the damn reds are back in Russia! You could have swore Yeltsin was making a mountain of a mole hill, but here it was, right in front of your eyes, the worst possible surprise you could have. Just after the Republican national convention, here they gain the best possible reason as to why they should come back as your term as given Moscow back to the commies! We have to do something!

You’re in Hartford, Connecticut. To your right stands Senator Dole—the poor old soul. As he wraps up his opening statement, you wonder: why did he run? Doesn’t he see the polls? This has to be one of the most lopsided races in recent memory, and he’s the one taking the punches for all to see. Maybe it doesn’t matter to him. Maybe he sees something you don’t. But if that’s the case, you’ve got to stop him here. For his own good, and for the country’s, send him into retirement.

You and Lamar stand across from each other – San Diego is friendly territory for you at this point, but Lamar clearly feels like he’s behind enemy lines. You enter this debate the favorite, and Lamar’s speaking style may make this debate fatal for his chances. How’re we bringing this election home tonight, Bill?

As you stand behind the podium in the Bushnell Center, the massive insult of implying you and Buchanan are alike really sinks in. He keeps sending you these little glares while Jim Lehrer reads out the rules, you deny him even a glance. What has your prep been focused on?

As you stand behind the podium in the Bushnell Center, the massive insult of implying you and Buchanan are alike really sinks in. He keeps sending you these little glares while Jim Lehrer reads out the rules, you deny him even a glance. What has your prep been focused on?

You and Wilson stand across from each other—San Diego may be his home, but it’s your crowd. You shake hands respectfully and meet his empty, beady eyes for a moment before the debate begins. Wilson’s got the momentum, spinning your successes as inadequate and your failures as glaring. How’re you going to shake that narrative, Slick?

For a media guy, Forbes sure is an unusual personality. You observe him practicing gesticulation while Jim Leher reads the rules of the debate, and trying to hide a smirk. By most people’s expectations, this will be a stomp. But that means Forbes will be benefiting from low expectations. Tread carefully, Slick — a strong Forbes performance could be a fiasco.

For a media guy, Forbes sure is an unusual personality. You observe him practicing gesticulation while Jim Leher reads the rules of the debate, and trying to hide a smirk. By most people’s expectations, this will be a stomp. But that means Forbes will be benefiting from low expectations. Tread carefully, Slick — a strong Forbes performance could be a fiasco.

Senator Gramm shakes your hand with a firm squeeze, locking eyes with you in a silent challenge as Jim Lehrer explains the rules. But as soon as the cameras roll, his expression shifts to a practiced grin, smoothly launching into why your foreign and domestic policies have been a total failure. It’s clear, he wants a fight, but he wants it clean. Will you indulge?

An attorney versus an attorney. As you skim your debate notes under the sweltering lights of the Bushnell Center, a wave of nostalgia hits, a reminder of past battles fought and won. The moment is short-lived, interrupted as Arlen Specter strides over, extending his hand. A brief, firm shake, then back to your notes. Time to focus. What’s the best way to hit Specter tonight?

These past four years, you’ve met so many world leaders, titans of industry, and military experts that you’re awed by few. But the way Powell saunters in, a stony gaze commanding the room, you’re man enough to admit you’re nervous. A lot more than during the ‘92 debates. What’s your tactic to handle him?

It’s time to face Bush head to head, without Perot to steal the show. When you get there, you see him. He's old, creaky, yet the most determined you've seen him. You can tell he's learned from his mistakes. He didn't even bring his watch. It's almost time, what are you gonna focus on?

You've always supported addressing the issue of climate change. Although you're by no means one of those tree-hugging hippies, you can still understand the common-sense essence of wanting a better tomorrow. After sending Al to the UN to figure out a solution, you've finally sat down to read the agreement he brokered. The ''Kyoto Protocol'' looks to involve the world’s 36 richest countries, while providing environmentally-friendly economic aid to the lesser-developed ones. It sounds good, but you know 90% of Republicans aren’t going to agree to this. Most of them are either misinformed, or just plain pissed that China isn't a part of it.

The Bosnian War has left 101,000 Bosniaks, Croats, and Serbs dead. Despite our aid to Bosnia and Croatia through covert bombing operations, the war shows no sign of ending. But a plan is being formulated by your National Security Advisor, Anthony Lake to promote peace and stability via an Inter-Entity Boundary Line, which would keep the nation unified while separating the various ethnic groups into their own territories. The final decision comes down to you: do you want to pursue negotiations or continue the bombings?

Since the midterms, the Republicans have carried this smug and cheeky confidence. To Gingrich, Satan himself, the mandate is so overwhelming that he has committed the House to pushing through a set of spending cuts and tax reductions, including cuts to Medicare. And now, they think themselves so grand as to threaten you with a government shutdown if you or your Cabinet overstep on education. This cannot happen.

With total control of both legislative branches, Gingrich, Satan himself, is able to simply power through anything he wants and overrule any veto you may bring. Elected on a platform of youth and change, you now find yourself politically defanged. Some are even calling you a lame duck. After conferring with your Cabinet, the challenge is clear: what can you do now, as the Republicans prepare to dismantle everything that ever helped the people?

You can see it in his face, Gingrich, Satan himself, is frustrated. Without the landslide victory he had worked so hard to achieve, the man who loved to shout and never compromise is now forced to do just that. The question is: how much will you agree to give? After all, you've met with your Cabinet, and they remind you that you're as responsible for the financial well-being of the nation as he is, aren’t you?

That budget was a slog to get through but here we are now! It's finally going to be voted on. You have more than the majority of congressmen needed to pass it but the last few month have made it very clear that this doesn't mean much as those cross party coalition pushing for special interest have made themselves clear. Now, there's just one way to see.

Now, there's justone way to see.

It’s been a week since that moment with Monica, a young intern you never should’ve gotten involved with, and the world still turns. The staff still moves. The press still smiles. Hillary still stands. That’s what matters. But your thoughts won’t quiet. What were you thinking? How could you cheat on your wife, a woman who’s stood by you for all these years? Don’t play dumb. This isn’t the first time. You’re still tangled up in the Paula Jones case, hoping the Supreme Court doesn’t take it up. Settling might make it all go away, but it would look like guilt. So... what now?

As people begin to look at the numbers, they appear staggering over the past four years. The deficit has always been down, down, down, and down. And suddenly, you cannot quite believe it — you see, for the first time, green numbers next to the chart as it crosses the line back into positive. 1996 is predicted to be a budget surplus!

People can't get enough of those photos you have with Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat, pushing for final peace in the Middle East. However, while the Oslo Accord is their impulse, the wounds of war are deep. Too many have already died, and many more still harbor hate for their neighbor. Without the aid of the entire world, poverty and desperation will once more drive a wedge between Israeli and Palestinian.

You get a series of increasingly tense phone calls as you hear Yitzhak Rabin is trying to also settle his struggle with Syria while pushing for peace with Palestine. Everyone is shouting, people on his right calling him over-compromising, people on his left saying he's giving breadcrumbs, Syria calling for immediate withdrawal from the Golan, and many, many more voices screaming. As the second part of Oslo is soon to come, we must have a clear proposal.

As the memory of Yitzhak's death is still fresh in the people's memories, and as the leading coalition was barely holding on without their leader, the new Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, called for early elections. Many think it will be a tough race, as the right is fighting as one under the young Benjamin Netanyahu, who has his own plan for peace with Palestine. Only time will tell who wins.

scenarioDescription:
Bill Clinton cannot believe he’s here. Gliding through town halls and across stages nationwide, he shared a modern vision, a ''third way'' forward. By uniting America’s diverse strands, he built a broad coalition that carried him through the wreckage of recession and into the White House, toppling the once-unshakable George Bush.

Now he sits in the same office once held by his hero, John F. Kennedy. He looks out the window and remembers where, and why, he started: Hope. The scandals, the pressure, the questions, they come with the territory. He’s learned that. But he understands the stakes now: to prove he’s not just the boy who made it out of Arkansas, but the man who can lead the free world, and change it.

tooltips.value: My dream and nightmare. The smartest person in the room, and sometimes the hardest to love.
White House royalty
Met the wrong man in the wrong place at the wrong time.
Several Travel Office staffers were fired, allegedly to make room for personal friends.
Arkansas State Troopers allege that they procured women for then-Governor Clinton
Zoë Baird and Kimba Wood, nominees for positions in the Justice Department, were found to have employed illegal immigrants as nannies.
Allegation that Air Force One was delayed for to hours while President Clinton had a haircut.
Allegations of shady dealings tied to a failed Arkansas real estate venture.
Childhood buddy turned Chief of Staff, a nice man in over his head
Wall Street banker turned economic czar. Calm, credible, and centrist.
Secretary of Labour, Shorty. Probably the most liberal man in the cabinet.
He knew Jack Kennedy, he was a friend of his... The veteran Texas senator is one of the biggest names in your cabinet.
A California budget hawk with an iron fist in a velvet glove.
First female AG, you're welcome
Courteous to a fault, and unfit for the age of knives."
